thread.title: Morning Spin: Decision day for Cook County Democrats on yanking Brown backing
thread.title_full: Morning Spin: Decision day for Cook County Democrats on yanking Brown backing - Chicago Tribune

author: Tribune staff report
title: Morning Spin: Decision day for Cook County Democrats on yanking Brown backing
text:
Welcome to Clout Street: Morning Spin, our weekday feature to catch you up with what's going on in government and politics from Chicago to Springfield.
Topspin
It's Friday, Oct. 23, the day after Park Ridge native Hillary Clinton had her day on Capitol Hill on Benghazi.
Cook County Democratic party leaders will meet this morning to vote on whether to rescind their endorsement of Circuit Court Clerk Dorothy Brown, who's under federal investigation.
The gathering of 50 ward committeemen and 30 suburban township committeemen unfolds behind closed doors at 11 a.m. at Erie Cafe in River North.
Some Democrats called for the party to reconsider the Brown endorsement on the grounds she denied she was under investigation when asked about the issue during August slate-making.
Brown, who is seeking a fifth term, told ABC-7 this week that she was met on the sidewalk near her home early this month by an FBI agent who said he had a subpoena for her cellphone, which she said she gave him.
According to ABC-7, Brown said she did not know who was the target of the federal investigation, but that "these kinds of things happen to people in my type of position all the time."
In May 2014, the Tribune reported federal authorities joined an investigation launched by the Cook County state's attorney's office into the sale of a North Lawndale building owned by Narendra Patel, a longtime campaign donor to Brown and a west suburban businessman.
The couple then sold the rundown building for $100,000 to developer Musa Tadros, county documents show.
Neither Brown nor her husband has been charged with wrongdoing.
County Democratic Chairman Joseph Berrios said the central committee's first action today will be to hold a roll call on whether to withdraw Brown's endorsement. If that happens, he said, Brown would have the opportunity to appear before the central committee to present her credentials along with others seeking party backing.
Several people — including Alds. Michelle Harris , 8th, and Walter Burnett , 27th; and attorney Jacob Meister — have expressed interest in gaining the Democratic endorsement for circuit clerk if Brown's slating is rescinded, party leaders said privately. (John Byrne)
What's on tap
* Mayor Rahm Emanuel will speak at the U.S.-China Sister Cities conference, open up a Mag Mile clothing store and talk at the Jewish National Fund’s conference.
* Gov. Bruce Rauner has no public schedule.
From the notebook
*Bully: Spike Lee calls Emanuel a “bully,” says mayor tried to “bully” him. And, for good measure, says a couple of mayor’s aldermen are “bootlickers." From the context, appears he's referring to Ald. David Moore, 17th, and Ald. Will Burns, 4th. ( Read the whole Q and A in Chicago magazine).
*Just a regular guy? Gov. Rauner acted as a pitchman for a Springfield business Thursday, bellying up to the counter to sample a breakfast horseshoe at Charlie Parker's diner.
The dish is a heaping pile of bacon, cheese sauce, sausage gravy and hash browns piled on top of an English muffin. The diet buster is in the running for a $25,000 prize from Thomas' English muffins.
"The good news is that the doctor told me I had super low cholesterol," Rauner joked with owner Mike Murphy before digging in as cameras rolled. "This is an entire food source of everything you'd possibly want to live off of all in one forkful." (Monique Garcia)
*CTU trick or treat: The Chicago Teachers Union will hold its annual “Legislators Educators Appreciation Dinner” (the event’s stated theme is “ Changing What We Cannot Accept ”) at Plumbers Hall next Friday, Halloween eve.
This year’s fete comes one year after union President Karen Lewis made a videotaped appearance there to back Cook County Commissioner Jesus “Chuy” Garcia’s mayoral campaign after a brain tumor ended her own prospective bid for the mayor’s office.
Lewis is back at work now, with plans to seek another term at the union’s helm, and is scheduled to deliver the evening’s keynote address instead of Garcia this time.
Corned beef will be on the menu, as usual, but it remains to be seen whether a group of teachers will show up in superhero costumes like they did last year. A $50 per head donation to CTU’s political action committee gains admission. (Juan Perez Jr.)
*Bad Mood(y’s): Illinois credit downgraded by another rating agency this week.
*Alderman loses bet, gets Smurfy: Ald. James Cappleman is a true Cubs fan. Unfortunately for him .
*Personnel file: Mayoral press secretary Tarrah Cooper has left the Emanuel administration to establish a new office in Chicago for Mercury Public Affairs. She’s the third press shop staffer to depart in recent months.
*The Sunday Spin: On this week’s “Sunday Spin,” airing from 7 to 9 a.m. Sunday on WGN-AM 720, Tribune political writer Rick Pearson speaks with Democratic political strategist Tom Bowen about his opposition to a proposed state constitutional amendment aimed at curbing political considerations in the drawing of legislative district boundaries. Also on the show is Tribune City Hall reporter John Byrne in advance of the City Council’s scheduled vote on Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s budget and property tax increase. Finally, former political strategist Michael Golden, author of “Unlock Congress,” joins the show to discuss his ideas to get Washington working again.
What we're writing
* Rauner responds to Edgar, Thompson criticism of state government.
*Judge to review records in Hastert civil suit.
Follow the money
* Senate Republican leader Christine Radogno of Lemont reported nearly $42,000 from 14 contributors, including $10,000 from Health Care Service Corp.
* Track campaign contribution reports in real time with this Tribune Twitter account: https://twitter.com/ILCampaignCash
Beyond Chicago
* Presidential race, Republican side: Trump dip in Iowa .
* Presidential race, Democratic side: So many Benghazi takes .
 Commercial Real Estate Democratic Party Chicago Teachers Union Park Ridge Joe Berrios David H. Moore Chicago City Hall
